Good idea to get a sword made for tameshigiri. Sorry
for the crass commercial message but we have great
tatami cutting swords. They take the beating. Bob
Elder East Coast Martial Art Supplies in Orlando. 
--- sigp210 <sigp210@...> wrote:

> Enore,
> 
> As pointed out in other posts, this is not a
> personal attack, but you
> did ask for opinions and I think they have been
> unanimous. 
> If you need a blade for cutting, then why not
> commision a modern
> shinsakuto made to your specifications?
> These swords were made that way for a reason, and I
> feel that saying
> it would be better with a hi, is like saying that
> you think a Picasso
> needs more red, and then considering adding it. 
> Even if it would be
> better..it is not how the artist intended it to be.
> The swords were
> once made for battle...but now they are universally
> considered art. 
> We collectors are always striving to get swords that
> are as close as
> possible to how they were originally  manufactured.
> Yes...suriage is
> tolerated...but not prefered. It is accepted because
> it cannot be
> undone. No-one here would have an old sword
> shortened because they
> think it would look better that way. 
> Adding hi may not be noticable, but it is not the
> chosen action by
> anyone except yourself..and since we are preserving
> these swords for
> future generations...I just feel it is selfish to
> change it. The next
> generation may want it shortened..the next will add
> a horimono..and
> after a few generations what was a nice Shinto sword
> becomes another
> back-of-the-cupboard relic. None of this can be
> undone, and the fact
> that others may do it does not make it the correct
> action.
> 
> Just my 2c on behapf of future generations looking
> for original Nihonto.
> 
> Brian
> 
> 
> --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Enore Gardonio
> <egardon@...> wrote:
> >
> > Its a Shinto blade not Koto. If I do put the hi on
> it will not be for 
> > whistling purposes. What makes people think that I
> would shallowly ruin 
> > an old blade. I see no reason why the blade cannot
> be used for Iaido
> and 
> > adding a hi on it does not ruin the blade, if done
> by a proper smith in 
> > Japan. The blade can still be appreciated. We are
> obviously looking at 
> > this from opposite ends. If done correctly and I
> presented you with the 
> > blade for the first time you would probably not
> know that it was
> modified.
> > Enore
> > 
> 
>
